question: Given a set of intervals $I = \{(s_1, f_1), (s_2, f_2), ..., (s_n, f_n)\}$, find the maximum number of mutually compatible intervals. Describe the greedy choice property.
solution:
Sort the intervals by their finish times $f_i$ in non-decreasing order. Always select the interval with the earliest finish time that is compatible with the previously selected intervals. 

**Time Complexity:** $O(n \log n)$ due to sorting.

question: Define the recurrence relation for the **Longest Common Subsequence** problem for two sequences $X$ and $Y$.
solution:
Let $c[i, j]$ be the length of the LCS of sequences $X_i$ and $Y_j$. 

$$c[i, j] = \begin{cases} 0 & \text{if } i=0 \text{ or } j=0 \\ c[i-1, j-1] + 1 & \text{if } i,j > 0 \text{ and } x_i = y_j \\ \max(c[i, j-1], c[i-1, j]) & \text{if } i,j > 0 \text{ and } x_i \neq y_j \end{cases}$$

question: What is the Master Theorem case for the recurrence $T(n) = 2T(n/2) + n$?
solution:
Here $a=2, b=2, f(n)=n$. 
We compare $n^{\log_b a} = n^{\log_2 2} = n^1$ with $f(n) = n$. 
Since they are equal, this is Case 2 of the Master Theorem. 

$$T(n) = \Theta(n \log n)$$

question: Explain the Max-Flow Min-Cut theorem.
solution:
The maximum amount of flow possible from source $s$ to sink $t$ in a flow network is equal to the capacity of a minimum cut $(S, T)$ in that network. 

Mathematically: $|f| = c(S, T)$ where $(S, T)$ is a cut with minimum capacity.

question: Does the Greedy approach work for the 0/1 Knapsack problem? Why or why not?
solution:
No, the Greedy approach does **not** work for 0/1 Knapsack. 
Choosing the item with the highest value-to-weight ratio can lead to empty space in the knapsack that could have been filled by a combination of other items yielding a higher total value. 

Dynamic Programming is required.
